history.origin: Printed calendar sheets from 1909 with handwriting and illustrations added by Mary Behrend, found inside an envelope in a family baby album.

div2.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.

figure.figDesc: Two rooms of a house are drawn; the upstairs, which has a mother (Mary), her husband (can't remember his name), and a child (Warren). Meanwhile, two people are downstairs, and they appear to be playing pool. The upstairs and downstairs rooms are clearly labelled, and ironically, are the easiest things to read besides the date and copyright information.

div2.ab:
The new rooves are very nice
and please both Ernst and Molly.
For now he has a billiard room
and she, das Kind, by golly.
div2.note: This is one of the few pages written entirely in pencil. Unfortunately, this means that it isn't very clear to read. From what little I can gather, Mary's family had the roof of their house redone and ordered a billiard/pool table, and either her husband or someone they know loves to play pool.

div2.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.

figure.figDesc: This one is interesting: there are two cutouts from articles, with one containing a drawing of a large woman and a small man with some text underneath with while the second cutout only consists of text. It is unknown where it came from.

div2.ab:
In case a woman is so large around the waist
That her husband can't hug her all at once, he
can take one hug, make a chalk mark so as to
know where he left off and where to commence
next time going round.

I hope I won't be large
again

Care of the Hands in Winter
Floreance. Proper washing and wiping of
the hands will prevent much redness and rough-
ness of the skin. Wipe every part thoroughly
with a soft, absorbent towel. Then rub in some
of the following lotion: One ounce of each
glycerine and rose-water; ten drops of tincture
of benozine.
div2.note: I took care to transcribe the printed text in the images. I couldn't read what was entirely in pencil, but I got most of it. It sounds like she hasn't had Warren yet, so she is worried about her weight and is reading up on skin-care.

div2.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.

figure.figDesc: Someone (possibly Mary) is tending to a man's hair. She appears to be rubbing in shampoo ( or "scalp food", as she called it) and the woman appears to be singing or talking. The image is drawn in pencil and what appears to be watercolor, with the woman's hair obscuring the year number.

div2.note: I wonder: if this is Mary, did she cut and clean her husband's hair? Was she at a hairdresser waiting to have her hair done and saw this while she was waiting? Did they have a housekeeper of some kind? I have so many questions.

div2.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.

figure.figDesc: An infant is seen from behind. Looking closely, the image was made with a different type of paper. It was likely first printed in a magazine, cut out, and glued onto the page.

div2.ab:
That little spot in the
back of his neck
is the sweetest spot to
kiss I know
so I kiss him there
and hold him close
just because I love him so.
div2.note: It's clear that Mary is talking about her son Warren here. From the way she talks about him, he is a few months old (or less) and she absolutely adores him. If Warren is her first born child, then her joy from being around him makes a lot more sense.

div2.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.

figure.figDesc: A basket of fruits and vegetables is drawn using pencil and watercolor. The pencil is faded, but surprisingly legible.

div2.ab:
Here's a basket of things from
the garden
which help to reduce Becker's bill
Fresh vegetables always taste
nicest
So I am sure these will;
div2.note: I don't know if Becker has been mentioned before, but he appears he is a close friend of the Behrends. I remember that around this time more people were encouraged to start gardens (If I am remembering correctly), and Maryoffering fresh fruits and vegetables to someone, friend or neighbor, was a sign of goodwill.

div2.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.

figure.figDesc: An anthropomorphic peach or tomato lady is on the left of the page and a pear lady is drawn on the right. They are made with pencil and watercolor, and the text is about them.

div2.ab:
Miss Peach has such a
lovely face
I think it would be
out of place
to tell you that,
tho' never tart,
she has a very
stony heart;
Poor Miss Pear has a
swollen cheek;
She's had it, too,
for nearly a week;
If you ask me now
how can that be -
I'll tell you why:
She fell out of a tree!
div2.note: I can tell, from reading enough pages, that Warren has already been born. Since he's a young child, I wouldn't be surprised if Mary tried writing little stories to read to her son. It's almost like something out of a children's book, and it reminds me of some of the books I had read to me when I was young.

div2.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.

figure.figDesc: There is no image here, just red pen.

ab.quote:
To live in hearts or leave behind,
is not to die.

div2.note: This is one of the most bizarre calendar pages out of the collection. It's one of, if not, the only page that doesn't have a drawing or photo on it. I wonder if she couldn't think of anything to draw. Maybe she didn't have time, or maybe this quote inspired her. Who knows?

div2.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.

figure.figDesc: There is a photo of two men and two women walking down a street, with two other people walking in the background. Everyone in the foreground is wearing black, while everyone in the background is dressed in brighter colors.

ab.quote:
will love him dearly,
have a cheerful home"

div2.note: I can't read everything, but it appears this was written after attending a funeral or recently losing a loved one. Unfortunately, I can't make out most of her handwriting here, and I wonder if that's her in the picture.

div2.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.

figure.figDesc: This is either a bunch of rabbits hopping together or one rabbit moving really quickly. Don't know for sure.

div2.note: This is a stark contrast from the previous page; it was somber, likely from losing someone close, and now she's drawn something silly about rabbits, a common "game" animal. Maybe she knew someone who was hunter, since rabbit are common game animals when they are not being kept as pets.
